title: Relates to assault against employees and agents of the department of juvenile justice of the city of New York
summary: Provides for assault against employees and agents of the department of juvenile justice of the city of New York to be a class C felony; sets forth sentencing; further makes technical corrections relating to assaults on medical or related personnel and firefighters.

memo:
BILL NUMBER:S2206

TITLE OF BILL:
An act
to amend the penal law, in relation to assault against employees and
agents of the department of juvenile justice of the city of New York and
making technical corrections relating to assaults on medical or related
personnel and firefighters

SUMMARY OF PROVISIONS:
The bill amends Penal Law § 120.05 to make physically injuring an
employee or agent of the Department of Juvenile Justice of the City
of New York ("DJJ") assault in the second degree, a Class D felony,
where such physical injury is caused with the intent to prevent the
agent or employee's performance of a lawful duty.

The bill also amends Penal Law § 120.08 to make assault on an employee
or agent of the DJJ a Class C felony, when the assault is committed
with the intent to prevent the employee from performing a lawful duty
and results in serious physical injury. Additionally, the bill amends
Penal Law § 70.02 to reflect the expanded scope of the felony in
Penal Law § 120.08. Finally, the bill makes technical corrections to
include "medical or related personnel in a hospital emergency
department" in a consistent manner in Penal Law § 120.05 (3) and to
change the term "fireman" to the gender neutral "firefighter" in
Penal Law §§ 70.02, 120.05 and 120.08.

JUSTIFICATION:
Employees and agents of the New York City Department of Juvenile
Justice promote public safety by providing custody and care of
juveniles accused of committing delinquent or criminal acts. The
Penal Law provides special sanctions for serious assaults against
several categories of public employees who perform a public safety
function, including police, peace officers, firefighters, emergency
medical personnel and transit personnel. The purpose of this
legislation is to afford the employees and agents of the DJJ similar
protection and to hold juveniles accountable for their actions in
detention by heightening the seriousness and
consequences of assaulting any member of the Department's staff at the
three secure detention facilities it directly operates, at non-secure
detention facilities that it operates, either directly or by
contract, and in its court services and transportation unit
Department employees must be reasonably assured that the law provides
a deterrent to those who would commit criminal acts that could result
in serious injury. It is not only the safety of these public servants
that is at stake, but the welfare of our citizenry, since their
safety and well-being depends upon the ability of these public
servants to perform their duties unfettered by criminal acts of
interference.

With respect to the technical amendment to Penal Law § 120.05 (3), the
reference to "medical or related personnel in a hospital emergency

department" was not included in the 1998 amendment that added the
clause relating to the releasing of or failure to control an animal (L.
1998 Ch. 269) because of the almost simultaneous amendment to section
120.05 (3) that expanded the category of persons within the purview
of that section (L. 1998 Ch. 287)" The addition of that language here
would serve only to reconcile these independent amendments to section
120.05 (3).

LEGISLATIVE HISTORY:
2007-2008: S.5730 - Referred to Codes, Passed Senate
2009-2010: S.2116 - Referred to Codes

FISCAL IMPLICATIONS:
None.

EFFECTIVE DATE:
This act shall take effect on the ninetieth day after it shall have
become law.
